snippet: 'After lectures,' Carlyle writes, -'and considerable reading for " Cromwell," talking about scheme of London library, struggling and concocting towards what proved " Chartism," and more of the like, we set out together for Scotland by Liverpool about July 2 or 3, for Scotsbrig both of us in the first place, then she to Templand as headquarters, and, after leaving here, then to return to Scotsbrig,  all which took effect, my remembrance of it now very indistinct.'

snippet: Mrs. Welsh from Templand was certainly with us a second time at present.

title: Letters and memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle.

snippet: Two of our dearest friends are dangerously ill; John Mill, whom you have often heard me speak of, and John Sterling, whose novel, 'Arthur Coningsby,' I think I lent you at Templand.
